hero.title: Antacids
hero.subtitle: (Potassium hydrogen carbonate/sodium alginate)
hero.intro: Antacids work by neutralising the acid in your stomach. They also create a protective barrier at the top of your stomach to prevent reflux symptoms like heartburn.

faq.title: Antacids: facts you need to know
faq.subtitle: Straightforward answers to frequently asked questions.

list.title: How do you take antacids?
list.text:
Antacids should be taken when you feel the symptoms of reflux. Usually, this is just after meals or before you go to bed.

It’s recommended to take antacids as advised by a clinician or as directed in the patient information leaflet that comes with your medication. If you are prescribed any other medication, you should allow a 2-hour window on either side of taking an antacid, as it can affect absorption in the gut.

list.title: Do antacids have side effects?
list.text:
Antacids generally have no side effects for most people when they are taken in the right way.

There is a very rare chance of an allergic reaction that occurs in less than 1 in 10,000 patients. If symptoms such as swelling or a rash occur, you should stop taking the medication and consult a clinician.

list.title: Will I need antacids long term?
list.text:
Antacids are fine to take occasionally for symptoms of heartburn if overseen by a health professional.

If you need an antacid for more than 7 days in a row, it’s recommended to check in with a clinician to rule out any underlying conditions and to make sure that you’re on the best treatment plan for you.
